testimony.name: Layla Law-Gisiko
key_points: The proposal fails to address affordable housing needs
Increasing housing supply does not automatically result in more affordable housing
The initiative may reduce housing quality by allowing reduced standards
The proposal lacks assessment of environmental impact and infrastructure needs
Concerns about the transfer of development rights from landmarks potentially creating disproportionately large towers
Urges for mandatory affordable housing provisions
Calls for protection of housing standards and local oversight
Emphasizes the need for planning community infrastructure

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: The city of yes may be a housing proposal, but it is not really an affordable housing proposal.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote indicates that the speaker is discussing the UAP element, as it directly addresses the lack of focus on affordable housing in the proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: Many wrongly assume that increasing housing supply will automatically result in more affordable housing. This is a dangerous misconception.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This quote challenges the assumption that increasing housing supply (which is part of the UAP element) will lead to more affordable housing, showing that the speaker is discussing this aspect of the proposal.

quotes_indicating_discussion.text: New York must mandate affordable housing.
quotes_indicating_discussion.reasoning: This statement directly relates to the UAP element, suggesting that the current proposal doesn't do enough to mandate affordable housing.
